title: Create a simple algorithm in code (sequence and events)
short_name: Write a sequence of blocks in code
description: Students create a short program using block-based code (in CreatiCode) where a sprite follows a sequence of steps triggered by the green flag. Example: "When green flag clicked, move 10 steps, turn 90 degrees, move 10 steps, say 'Done!'" This is the first coded algorithm, focusing on sequence and events.

title: Add a simple if/then (conditional) to an algorithm
short_name: Add a choice to your algorithm
description: Students modify a given script to include an if/then condition (e.g., "If touching the goal, say 'Victory!'"). This embeds the conditional logic into code and shows how algorithms can respond differently based on conditions.

title: Use a loop in code for repetition
short_name: Use a repeat block in code
description: Students create a program that uses a repeat (or forever) block to execute a sequence multiple times. Example: Repeat 4 { turn 90 degrees } to spin in a square. This brings the conceptual idea of repetition into actual code.

title: Describe an algorithm in words after running code
description: After creating or being shown a program, students write or speak a description of what the algorithm does. Example: Given a script with sequence and a loop, they write "The sprite moves forward, then spins around 3 times." This reinforces understanding of algorithm behavior through language.

title: Create an algorithm to solve a simple problem
short_name: Design a program to solve a problem
description: Given a problem statement (e.g., "Make a sprite navigate to the goal without touching walls"), students design an algorithm from scratch (or refine a starter project) to solve it. This shifts focus from "following instructions" to "designing instructions to achieve a goal."

title: Optimize an algorithm (fewer steps or faster)
short_name: Improve an algorithm to use fewer steps
description: Students compare two algorithms that solve the same problem but one is more efficient (uses fewer blocks, repeats, or conditions). They refactor code to reduce redundancy. Example: replacing five `move 10` blocks with `repeat 5 { move 10 }` or removing an unnecessary check.

title: Use a variable (counter) in an algorithm
short_name: Use a variable to track something
description: Students create a variable (e.g., `score`, `steps`, `lives`) and use it in their algorithm to track state. Example: increment a score when touching a coin, or decrement lives on collision. This introduces variables as part of algorithm design.

title: Trace and predict the behavior of a multi-step algorithm
short_name: Predict what a complex program does
description: Given an algorithm with sequence, branching, loops, and/or a variable, students trace through it step-by-step and predict the final outcome (e.g., final position, final variable value, sequence of events). This builds mental models of complex behavior.

title: Design an algorithm from a flowchart or pseudocode
description: Given a flowchart or pseudocode description of an algorithm, students translate it into block-based code in CreatiCode. Example: A flowchart shows "Start → Ask for a number → If number > 10, say 'Big.' Else, say 'Small.' → End." Students implement this with if/else blocks and input.

title: Create a flowchart or pseudocode for an algorithm in code
short_name: Draw or describe an algorithm plan
description: Given a program (or a problem), students create a visual flowchart or write pseudocode to represent what it does or what it should do. This is the inverse of G5.01 and reinforces algorithm understanding through representation.

title: Compare two algorithms for the same problem
description: Given two algorithms that solve the same problem (e.g., finding the maximum number in a list), students compare them on criteria like correctness, efficiency (number of steps or iterations), readability, or use of variables. They articulate which is better and why.

title: Debug an algorithm that doesn't work correctly
description: Students are given an algorithm with a logical error (e.g., a loop that runs too many times, a condition with wrong comparison, or missing steps) and must identify and fix the error. This develops reasoning about algorithm correctness.

title: Analyze an algorithm's efficiency in different scenarios
short_name: Compare algorithm speed for different inputs
description: Students examine an algorithm's performance (number of steps) under different input sizes or conditions. Example: A linear search algorithm is faster on a small list than a binary search is on a small list, but they scale differently. Students compare counts of operations or run time.

title: Identify bias or unintended consequences in an algorithm
short_name: Spot fairness problems in an algorithm
description: Students examine a simple algorithm (often a decision algorithm, like "grading scale" or "student selection criteria") and discuss how it might unfairly impact certain groups. Example: An algorithm that selects only tall students for a team might inadvertently exclude shorter students who are equally qualified. Students articulate the bias and suggest improvements.

title: Create a flowchart for a multi-step problem
short_name: Draw a flowchart for a complex task
description: Students create a detailed flowchart that represents a more complex algorithm with multiple decision points and loops. Example: A flowchart for a simple game turn (ask for input, validate, update score, check if won, repeat if not). This strengthens structured thinking about algorithms.

title: Implement an algorithm in code from a complex flowchart
description: Students receive a detailed flowchart with multiple branches and loops, then implement it in block-based or introductory text code. This is a direct application of algorithm planning to code.

title: Recognize and apply common algorithm patterns (search, sort, accumulate)
description: Students learn to recognize and name common algorithmic patterns: linear search (find first matching item), simple sort (reorder items), accumulation (collect sums or counts), and simulation (repeat action with updates). When given a problem, they choose the appropriate pattern.

title: Understand why different algorithms are chosen for different problems
short_name: Choose the right algorithm for the task
description: Given a problem, students consider multiple possible algorithms and justify which is most appropriate based on efficiency, clarity, or fit. Example: Why use a specific sorting algorithm over repeated swaps? Why use binary search instead of linear? This develops algorithmic decision-making.

title: Represent an algorithm in pseudocode or text code
description: Students transition from block-based code to pseudocode or simple text-based code representation. They write an algorithm in plain language with code-like structure (e.g., "for each item in list: if item > max, set max = item"). This bridges to more formal programming.

title: Analyze an algorithm for correctness on edge cases
short_name: Test an algorithm on tricky inputs
description: Students test an algorithm (given in code or pseudocode) on edge cases (empty input, single item, maximum/minimum values, repeats) and identify if it fails and why. This develops rigorous thinking about algorithm robustness.

title: Design an algorithm for a simulation or model
short_name: Create an algorithm to simulate a process
description: Students design an algorithm that simulates a real-world process or system (e.g., a predator-prey ecosystem, weather patterns with simple rules, or traffic flow). The algorithm repeatedly updates state and checks conditions to model behavior over time. This applies algorithmic thinking to simulation.

title: Understand recursion conceptually (algorithm calling itself)
description: Students encounter the concept that some problems can be solved by breaking them into smaller versions of themselves (recursion conceptually, not yet in code). Example: "To find the largest number in a list, find the larger of the first number and the max of the rest." They understand the base case and recursive case but don't yet implement it in code (that's a high school topic).

title: Analyze the impact of an algorithm on society or individuals
description: Students examine a real-world algorithmic system (e.g., social media recommendation, search rankings, college admission scoring) and analyze its societal impacts. They consider who benefits, who might be harmed, ethical implications, and possible improvements.

title: Refactor a complex algorithm for clarity or efficiency
description: Given a working but convoluted or inefficient algorithm (in block or text code), students refactor it to be clearer, more modular, or more efficient. Example: breaking a long script into named procedures, extracting repeated logic into a loop, or optimizing a search to avoid redundant checks.

title: Create a simple flowchart with start, end, and action boxes
short_name: Draw a flowchart for a task
description: Students create a flowchart using basic symbols (start oval, action rectangle, end oval) to represent a simple algorithm (e.g., "How to make a sandwich" or "How to greet a friend"). This is the first formal graphical representation of algorithms.

title: Trace a program with an if/else condition
description: Given a script with one simple `if` or `if/else` block (e.g., "if key pressed, move right, else move left"), students trace through it by following the condition and predicting which branch executes and what the outcome is.

title: Match a flowchart to code with a decision
description: Students match a flowchart with a diamond decision symbol to a script that uses an `if/else` block. This reinforces that flowcharts and code represent the same algorithmic logic.

title: Trace a loop and count iterations
description: Given a simple script with a `repeat` loop (e.g., `repeat 3 { move 10 }`), students trace it to determine how many times the action inside happens and/or what the total effect is (e.g., "the sprite moves 30 steps total").

title: Create a flowchart with loops
short_name: Draw a flowchart with a loop symbol
description: Students create a flowchart that includes a loop or iteration, using the appropriate flowchart symbol (a back arrow or loop rectangle) to represent "do this again." This introduces algorithmic thinking about repetition as a formal construct.

title: Trace nested conditions and predict outcomes
short_name: Trace code with multiple if/else blocks
description: Students trace a script with two or more sequential `if/else` blocks (not yet nested in the code sense, but multiple conditional decisions in sequence) and follow the logic to predict the final state.

title: Convert a story or real-world process into pseudocode
description: Given a natural-language description of a process (e.g., "make a peanut butter sandwich") or a picture algorithm, students write simple pseudocode (everyday language steps, not Python, but more formal than pictures) such as:

title: Trace a script with a loop and condition together
short_name: Trace code with loop and condition
description: Students trace a script that combines a loop with a conditional inside (e.g., `repeat 5 { if touching edge, bounce else move }`), following the logic through multiple iterations and branching.

title: Create a detailed flowchart with multiple branches
short_name: Draw a complex flowchart with several decision points
description: Students design a flowchart with multiple decision diamonds, multiple paths, and loops, representing a more realistic algorithm (e.g., a decision tree for choosing an activity based on time and weather, or steps to find an item in a list).

title: Trace an algorithm with variables and counters
description: Students trace a script that declares and updates a variable (e.g., a counter or accumulator) through multiple steps or loop iterations, tracking how its value changes and predicting the final value.

title: Write pseudocode for a multi-step algorithm
short_name: Write pseudocode with loops and conditions
description: Students write structured pseudocode (not code, but formal step-by-step language) for an algorithm that includes sequence, loops, and conditionals. Example:

title: Compare two algorithms and reason about efficiency
short_name: Compare two algorithms for the same task
description: Students are given two different algorithms (flowcharts, pseudocode, or code) that solve the same problem and are asked to compare them in terms of steps, clarity, or efficiency. They articulate reasoning (e.g., "Algorithm A uses a loop, so it's shorter" or "Algorithm B is clearer because...").

title: Create a flowchart for a guessing game
short_name: Design a flowchart for a game algorithm
description: Students create a complete flowchart for a simple guessing or decision-making game (e.g., "Higher or Lower" or "Rock-Paper-Scissors") with multiple branches, loops, and decision points, demonstrating understanding of complex algorithmic structure.

title: Trace code with nested loops and variables
short_name: Trace nested loops with variable changes
description: Students trace a script with nested loops and variable updates (e.g., a nested loop that fills a 2D grid, or loop within loop with a counter), predicting final variable values and patterns produced.

title: Write pseudocode with nested structures
short_name: Write pseudocode with nested loops and conditions
description: Students write pseudocode for algorithms with nested loops or loops containing complex conditionals (e.g., a loop that counts items matching a criteria, or nested loops for a grid). Example:

title: Compare algorithm representations (flowchart vs. pseudocode vs. code)
short_name: Convert between flowchart, pseudocode, and code
description: Students translate a simple algorithm from one representation to another (e.g., from a flowchart to pseudocode, or from pseudocode to code), recognizing that all represent the same logic.

title: Trace an algorithm with state changes over time
short_name: Trace a simulation algorithm step by step
description: Students trace an algorithm that simulates a process or system over multiple timesteps (e.g., a ball rolling, a population growing, or a search process narrowing), tracking state changes and predicting behavior at future steps.

title: Design a flowchart for a sorting or search algorithm
short_name: Create a flowchart for finding or organizing data
description: Students create a flowchart for a simple algorithmic task such as linear search, bubble sort, or selection sort, using appropriate decision points and loops to represent the logic.

title: Analyze algorithm complexity and steps required
short_name: Count steps in algorithms and compare efficiency
description: Students analyze two algorithms that solve the same problem and count or estimate the number of steps (or time complexity in intuitive terms) each requires for different input sizes, reasoning about which is more efficient.

title: Trace an algorithm and identify a bug or edge case
description: Students trace an algorithm (in pseudocode or code) with specific inputs, identify a case where it produces an incorrect result, and explain why (e.g., "When the list is empty, it crashes" or "When the target is at the end, it takes too long").

title: Write and test pseudocode for a non-trivial algorithm
short_name: Design and verify an algorithm with pseudocode
description: Students design pseudocode for a more complex algorithm (e.g., finding a median, checking if a number is prime, or simulating a simple game turn), then trace it with multiple test cases to verify correctness.

title: Create a flowchart for a decision-making process
short_name: Design a flowchart for a real-world decision
description: Students create a flowchart that models a real-world decision process (e.g., "Should I play outside?" with branches based on weather, temperature, and homework done, or "How to choose a book" based on genre and length preferences). This shows algorithm thinking applied to everyday reasoning.

title: Analyze and improve an algorithm's representation
short_name: Optimize how an algorithm is represented
description: Students are given an algorithm in one form (e.g., a verbose pseudocode) and are asked to improve its clarity or efficiency by refactoring its representation (e.g., shortening pseudocode, simplifying a flowchart, or adding comments to code).

title: Compare deterministic and probabilistic algorithms
short_name: Trace algorithms with and without randomness
description: Students trace two versions of an algorithm—one deterministic (same input always produces same output) and one probabilistic (uses randomness)—and articulate the differences, advantages, and disadvantages of each approach.

title: Decompose a project into scenes and features
short_name: Plan scenes and features for a project
description: Students take a medium‑sized project idea (game, story, or interactive app) and break it into major scenes (e.g., title, level 1, level 2, game over) and features for each (e.g., player movement, enemies, scoring). They create a simple outline or checklist.

title: Assign tasks in a team project
description: In a collaborative setting, students divide a project into individual tasks and assign them to team members (e.g., one student codes player movement, another codes enemies). They understand that breaking work into independent parts makes collaboration easier.

title: Create a to‑do checklist for a project
short_name: Build a task list with checkpoints
description: Students create a detailed task list for a coding project (e.g., "Make sprite move ☐, Add enemies ☐, Keep score ☐, Add sound ☐, Test the game ☐"). They learn to track progress and organize multi‑step work.

title: Assess whether a design is well‑decomposed
short_name: Judge if a plan breaks work into good parts
description: Students read a project plan or code structure and evaluate whether it logically breaks a problem into manageable pieces (e.g., "Does this plan separate player controls from enemy logic?" "Are the scenes clearly defined?"). They learn design criteria.

title: Refactor code to separate concerns
description: Students rewrite a monolithic script by extracting related blocks into custom blocks or separate sprites (e.g., moving enemy logic from the main script into an "enemy" sprite). This reinforces decomposition as a code quality principle.

title: Plan a multi‑level game with visuals
description: Students plan a multi‑level game (e.g., three levels with increasing difficulty) using flowcharts, sketches, or a written outline that shows how scenes connect and what happens in each. They learn to visualize dependencies.

title: Identify dependencies between tasks
description: Students read a project plan and identify which tasks must be done before others (e.g., "We need to design the sprite before we can code its movement"). They learn that decomposition is not just about breaking work apart, but organizing it in the right order.

title: Analyze a plan for efficiency
short_name: Judge a plan for wasted effort
description: Students read a project plan and identify redundant or inefficient steps (e.g., "Why code enemy movement twice for two different enemies?" or "Do we need a separate level for that?"). They learn to optimize decomposition.

title: Create a detailed project plan with stages
description: Students create a comprehensive plan for a moderately complex project (game, story, or app), broken into planning, coding, testing, and refinement stages. They list features, sprites, and milestones for each stage.

title: Use XO to brainstorm and refine a project plan
short_name: Use AI to help plan your project
description: Students use CreatiCode's XO AI assistant to brainstorm features, break a project into scenes, or refine their plan (e.g., "What scenes would a space game need?"). They learn that AI can support planning while they remain in control of the final design.

title: Refactor repeated logic into custom blocks
short_name: Use custom blocks to simplify code
description: Students take code with repeated patterns or logic (e.g., three enemies with the same movement code) and extract the logic into a custom block ("move enemy") that is called multiple times. This shows decomposition at the code level.

title: Trace a complex plan and identify components
description: Students read a detailed project plan or design document for a moderately complex system (e.g., a game with multiple levels, enemy types, UI menus) and identify the main components, how they interact, and which are dependent on others.

title: Refactor a design document to improve clarity
short_name: Reorganize a plan for better understanding
description: Students take a project design document that is unclear or poorly organized and restructure it (e.g., group related features, reorder scenes logically, add headings) to make it clearer. This teaches design documentation as a skill.

title: Use XO to generate a detailed project plan
short_name: Ask XO to help plan a complex project
description: Students use XO to generate a detailed plan for a project beyond simple games (e.g., an educational app, a story with branching paths, a data visualization). They refine XO's suggestions and create a final plan that reflects their own choices.

title: Analyze algorithms for decomposable parts
description: Students analyze a more complex algorithm (e.g., sorting, searching, or a game loop) and identify repeated or reusable logic that could be extracted into helper functions or custom blocks.

title: Design a multi-stage simulation plan
description: Students design a detailed plan for a simulation (e.g., ecosystem, physics, or social dynamics) that breaks it into components (agents, rules, interactions, data collection) and stages (setup, run, analyze). They learn systems thinking.

title: Use XO to brainstorm and structure a game design document
short_name: Create a GDD with XO help
description: Students use XO to brainstorm and structure a formal Game Design Document (GDD) for a moderately complex game (mechanics, level progression, art style, story beats). They learn a professional planning format while leveraging AI.

title: Decompose a data-driven app into models and views
short_name: Separate data and UI in a plan
description: Students plan an interactive data app (e.g., a leaderboard dashboard, quiz show, or survey tool) and explicitly separate the data model (what data is stored) from the UI (how it's displayed and interacted with). This teaches architectural decomposition.

title: Identify and fix poor decomposition in a plan
short_name: Find and improve bad design choices
description: Students review a project plan that has poor decomposition (e.g., all code in one sprite, no separation between logic and UI, unclear dependencies) and suggest improvements to make it more modular and maintainable.

title: Plan a multi-feature interactive app with XO
short_name: Design a complex app with AI guidance
description: Students use XO to help plan a large project with multiple interconnected features (e.g., a learning app with lessons, quizzes, progress tracking, and a leaderboard). They create a detailed architecture plan showing data flow, feature modules, and dependencies.

title: Create a formal project specification document
description: Students create a formal specification document for a non-trivial project, including requirements, system architecture, component descriptions, data schemas, and testing strategy. This mimics industry-standard documentation.

title: Analyze project complexity and estimate effort
description: Students read project plans of varying ambition and estimate the relative effort and risk (e.g., "This plan requires 5 different sprites and complex collision—it's a 6-week project." vs "This is simpler, maybe 2 weeks."). They learn to realistically assess scope.

title: Refactor a large codebase into modules
description: Students take a moderately complex, working program (e.g., a game with 200+ blocks) and refactor it by extracting repeated logic into custom blocks, separating concerns across sprites, and adding documentation. This is a real-world refactoring task.

title: Animal Pattern: What Comes Next?

incorrect.hint_text: Dog, cat, dog, cat... what comes next?

incorrect.hint_text: The pattern ABC repeated 5 times makes ABCABCABCABCABC!

title: Decompose a pattern into repeating units
short_name: Break a pattern into smaller pieces
description: Students analyze a visual or behavioral pattern (e.g., a row of stamps repeated multiple times to form a grid) and identify both the core unit that repeats and how many times it repeats, practicing decomposition.

title: Create a nested loop pattern
description: Students use a loop inside a loop to make patterns such as a row of stamps repeated multiple times (e.g., a 3×4 grid). They learn that nested loops multiply repetitions and allow compact expression of complex patterns.

title: Recognize a reusable behavior and create a custom block
short_name: Build a custom block for a repeated action
description: Students identify a repeating behavior in a script (e.g., "turn 90 degrees and move 20 steps" happening multiple times) and create a custom block (procedure) to encapsulate it, learning that custom blocks reduce duplication and improve readability.

title: Trace a nested pattern and count outcomes
description: Students read a script with nested loops (e.g., `repeat 3 { repeat 2 { stamp } }`) and predict how many times an action occurs or how many items appear, reinforcing multiplicative reasoning with patterns.

title: Analyze repeated code for abstraction opportunities
short_name: Find code to turn into a procedure
description: Students examine a longer script with several repeated multi‑block sequences (possibly with small parameter variations, like different move amounts) and identify which parts are reusable, considering how to parameterize them if needed.

title: Convert repeated blocks into a parameterized custom block
short_name: Create a custom block with parameters
description: Students refactor repeated code into a single custom block with parameters (e.g., `draw_polygon(sides, size)`). They learn that parameters allow one block to handle multiple similar tasks, achieving even greater code reuse than loops alone.

title: Refactor repeated code to use loops and custom blocks
short_name: Clean up code by combining loops and custom blocks
description: Students are given a script with both redundant copy‑paste code and opportunities to nest or parameterize. They refactor to use both loops (for iteration within a pattern) and custom blocks (for abstraction), learning when to apply each technique.

title: Assess effectiveness of a pattern recognition strategy
short_name: Evaluate how well a pattern is abstracted
description: Students compare two solutions to the same problem: one using repeated code and one using loops/custom blocks. They discuss or analyze which is more maintainable, clearer, and easier to modify, developing critical thinking about code quality.

title: Identify patterns in data and represent them with variables
short_name: Spot patterns in data with variables
description: Students examine a sequence of data values (e.g., scores increasing by 5 each round, or alternating values) and recognize the underlying pattern, then use variables and loops to generate or process similar data efficiently.

title: Create a reusable library of custom blocks
short_name: Build and use a custom block library
description: Students create several related custom blocks (e.g., `draw_polygon(sides, size)`, `draw_triangle`, `draw_square`) and recognize that this library of blocks encodes common patterns and can be applied in multiple projects, introducing the idea of code libraries and modularity.

title: Generalize a pattern into an algorithm
short_name: Turn a pattern into a reusable algorithm
description: Students take a specific repeating pattern (e.g., "draw a checkerboard") and generalize it into a parameterized algorithm (nested loops with dynamic sizing), so that changing one parameter produces the entire family of similar patterns.

title: Refactor a complex pattern into smaller, composable blocks
short_name: Decompose a big pattern into smaller reusable parts
description: Students take a complex visual pattern or animation (e.g., a fancy border made of repeated sections) and break it into smaller custom blocks that can be reused independently, understanding that patterns themselves can be built from simpler patterns.

title: Recognize structural patterns in algorithms
description: Students analyze code and identify common structural patterns (e.g., counter increments, accumulator updates, conditional nesting) that appear across different programs, learning that algorithms often follow recognizable templates.

title: Refactor repeated code into modular custom blocks
short_name: Turn repeated code into reusable procedures
description: Students are given longer projects with clearly repeated segments and asked to refactor them into well‑named custom blocks with appropriate parameters, improving code clarity and maintainability.

title: Analyze template projects and customize them systematically
short_name: Modify template projects for custom needs
description: Students examine a template project, understand its structure and key decision points, then make systematic modifications to adapt it for a different purpose (e.g., change a quiz template to use different questions, or adapt a game template with new rules), learning strategic reuse.

title: Compare efficiency of different pattern solutions
short_name: Evaluate which pattern approach is best
description: Students compare two solutions using different pattern techniques (e.g., nested loops vs list iteration, or custom blocks vs inline code) and reason about which is more efficient, readable, or maintainable for a given context.

title: Recognize iteration patterns in different contexts
short_name: Spot loop patterns in simulations and games
description: Students identify the iteration patterns underlying common game and simulation behaviors (e.g., "update physics every frame," "process each sprite," "check all collisions"), understanding that iteration is a fundamental building block.

title: Design composite algorithms using smaller algorithmic patterns
description: Students design a solution to a complex problem by recognizing that it can be decomposed into smaller, standard algorithmic patterns (e.g., a search pattern + an accumulator pattern) and combining them.

title: Optimize code by eliminating redundant patterns
short_name: Simplify code by removing repeated patterns
description: Students examine an existing project with redundant patterns and systematically refactor it, combining loops, nesting, and custom blocks to minimize duplication and improve clarity.

title: Explain how pattern recognition leads to better algorithm design
description: Students articulate how recognizing patterns in a problem (or in existing solutions) leads to better algorithm design, including improved efficiency, readability, and generalizability.

title: Recognize and leverage common algorithmic patterns
short_name: Use standard algorithm patterns in solutions
description: Students identify standard algorithmic patterns (e.g., linear search, accumulation, two‑pointer, divide‑and‑conquer) in problem descriptions and apply them effectively to solve problems, understanding that many problems can be solved by pattern matching to known solutions.

title: Design modular, reusable custom blocks for a project
short_name: Build a library of procedures for a project
description: Students design and build a suite of well‑named, well‑documented custom blocks (procedures) for a project, recognizing that good abstractions make code easier to reason about, test, and reuse across multiple scenes or game states.

title: Generalize a specific solution into a parameterized template
short_name: Turn a solution into a template others can reuse
description: Students take a working solution to a specific problem (e.g., a quiz with five questions) and generalize it into a reusable template with parameters (e.g., `make_quiz(num_questions, question_list)`) that others can adapt for different inputs, learning that good design anticipates reuse.

title: Analyze and justify choices in pattern‑based design
short_name: Explain trade‑offs in abstraction and reuse
description: Students examine a project and argue about design choices (e.g., "Should this be a custom block or inline code?" "Is this parameter necessary?"). They weigh factors like code length, clarity, flexibility, and performance in the context of the problem.
