title: Research computing in your community
short_name: How has computing changed our town or school?
description: Students research and describe how a computing technology or innovation has affected their local community (school uses computers for attendance, the library has digital catalogs, local businesses use websites, etc.). They see computing as part of their world.

title: How does technology respond to what people need?
description: Students examine historical examples where computing innovations were created to solve specific problems (email to communicate across distance, digital maps to navigate, text-to-speech to help people with reading difficulties). They understand design as a response to human need.

title: Compare how technology was different 50+ years ago
description: Students research or are shown what computing looked like decades ago (room-sized computers, punch cards, no internet, no smartphones) and compare it to today. They recognize massive change and progress.

title: Invent a solution to a problem
short_name: Design a new computing tool for a problem
description: Students identify a real problem they or their community faces and design or sketch a computing solution, applying the idea that computing tools are invented to meet needs.

title: Trace the evolution of a technology
short_name: How has one technology changed over time?
description: Students research and create a detailed timeline showing how one technology evolved (e.g., cell phones: 1973 Motorola brick → 1990s feature phones → 2000s smartphones → today's AI-enabled phones). They identify key milestones and reasons for change.

title: Identify pioneers from diverse backgrounds
short_name: Computing pioneers from around the world
description: Students learn about computing pioneers from diverse cultures, genders, ethnicities, and regions (Ada Lovelace, Alan Turing, Grace Hopper, Hedy Lamarr, Katherine Johnson, Euclid Lantern, and others). They recognize that computing history is global and inclusive.

title: Examine positive and negative societal impacts
short_name: What are the good and bad effects of a technology?
description: Students investigate a computing technology and articulate both positive impacts (e.g., social media enables connection) and negative impacts (e.g., social media can be addictive or spread misinformation). They develop balanced, critical perspective.

title: Unintended consequences of innovation
short_name: What problems did the technology create?
description: Students explore how a computing innovation, while solving one problem, sometimes created new challenges (e.g., cars improved transportation but increased pollution; the internet enabled communication but also cyberbullying). They think critically about side effects.

title: Analyze how a computing innovation changed society
short_name: How did this invention reshape the world?
description: Students examine a major computing innovation (the transistor, the microprocessor, the graphical user interface, the web, smartphones, AI) and explain how it fundamentally changed the way people lived, worked, learned, or communicated. They recognize computing as a driver of social change.

title: Limitations of old technologies
short_name: Why did old technology stop being used?
description: Students examine why certain computing technologies became obsolete (floppy disks, dial-up internet, desktop-only computers) and identify limitations that newer technologies overcame (slow speed, small storage, lack of portability). They understand technological progress through replacement cycles.

title: Contributions of diverse pioneers
short_name: Pioneers who shaped computing from many backgrounds
description: Students research and present on multiple computing pioneers, deliberately including women, people of color, and non-Western contributors whose work is often overlooked. They challenge narrow narratives and recognize global contributions (Ada Lovelace, Grace Hopper, Hedy Lamarr, Alan Kay, Guido van Rossum, and others from diverse backgrounds).

title: Computing in response to global challenges
short_name: How does computing help solve big problems?
description: Students examine how computing technologies have been developed to address large societal or environmental challenges (medical imaging for disease detection, models for climate prediction, apps for pandemic response, GPS for navigation and disaster response). They see computing as a tool for public good.

title: How challenges led to computing innovations
short_name: Problems that led to computing breakthroughs
description: Students examine specific historical or social challenges that motivated computing innovations. For example, World War II code-breaking drove computer development; massive data analysis needs inspired databases; accessibility needs drove assistive computing tools. They understand computing as a response to urgent human problems.

title: Roles of different groups in advancing computing
short_name: Who contributed to building computing technologies?
description: Students investigate how computing progress involved multiple actors: mathematicians and logicians developing theory, engineers building hardware, programmers writing software, entrepreneurs commercializing, and users driving demand. They recognize computing as a collaborative, multi-disciplinary endeavor.

title: Intended and unintended impacts of historical technologies
short_name: Good and bad outcomes of computing breakthroughs
description: Students analyze a historical computing technology for its intended benefits and unintended harms (e.g., databases enable efficient business but also enable surveillance; the internet enables information sharing but also spreads disinformation). They develop sophisticated thinking about technology and society.

title: How a historical practice led to modern ethical concerns
short_name: From the past to ethical issues today
description: Students trace a computing practice from history to a present-day ethical concern. For example, early data collection practices without consent → modern privacy violations; early AI systems trained on biased data → modern algorithmic bias; early surveillance tools → modern privacy erosion. They see ethics as rooted in historical choices.

title: Major eras of computing history
description: Students learn and distinguish major eras in computing history: mechanical computing (abacus, Babbage's difference engine), electronic/mainframe era (1940s–1960s), personal computer era (1970s–1980s), internet/web era (1990s–2000s), mobile and cloud era (2010s), and AI era (2020s). They understand how each era introduced different capabilities and challenges.

title: Key figures and their contributions
description: Students research and report on multiple notable computing figures from diverse backgrounds and eras (Charles Babbage, Ada Lovelace, Alan Turing, Grace Hopper, Steve Jobs, Bill Gates, Linus Torvalds, Sheryl Sandberg, etc.). They understand computing progress through the lens of individual and collaborative achievement.

title: Comparing historical computing innovations
short_name: How different innovations shaped the world
description: Students compare two or more historical computing innovations (e.g., transistor vs integrated circuit; TCP/IP vs HTML; graphical user interface vs command line) in terms of their effects on computing capabilities, accessibility, and society. They analyze both similarities and differences in impact.

title: Environmental and social impacts of computing evolution
short_name: Computing's effects on the environment and society
description: Students examine how computing technology expansion has affected the environment (e-waste, energy consumption of data centers, manufacturing pollution) and society (job displacement, digital divides, inequality, benefits of automation). They develop critical perspective on progress and trade-offs.

title: Policies and legislation shaping computing
short_name: Laws and rules that guide computing
description: Students examine policies and legislation that have shaped computing development and use: intellectual property laws, data protection regulations (GDPR, CCPA), accessibility requirements (Section 508), content moderation rules, AI governance proposals, etc. They understand that computing evolves within a regulatory and legal context.

title: Historical disparities in computing access and benefits
short_name: Who benefits from computing? Who doesn't?
description: Students analyze historical patterns showing how computing benefits and access have been distributed unequally across groups (gender disparities in tech careers, digital divides by geography and socioeconomic status, bias in AI training data, underrepresentation of women and people of color in computing). They connect history to present-day inequities.

title: Computing innovations responding to societal needs
description: Students research and analyze multiple computing innovations developed in response to specific societal needs or crises: medical computing for diagnosis and treatment, financial computing for transactions, educational technology for remote learning, disaster response apps, etc. They see computing as pragmatic problem-solving.

title: Futures thinking: Computing trends and implications
short_name: Where is computing headed and what matters?
description: Students examine current trends in computing (AI, quantum computing, biotechnology integration, internet of things, decentralization) and speculate about future implications for society, environment, work, and daily life. They develop forward-looking critical thinking.

title: Evaluate whether a technology choice is good for you
short_name: Is this a good choice for you?
description: Students evaluate whether using a particular technology suits their current needs and the likely consequences (e.g., "Is it a good idea to play a video game right before bed?" or "Should I use a voice app to do my homework when I need to learn?"). They weigh benefits and harms.

title: Identify both intended and unintended consequences of a technology
short_name: Expected and unexpected effects of technology
description: Students systematically list what a technology was intended to do and what unintended side effects it might have, recognizing that designers sometimes cannot predict all consequences.

title: Recognize AI and smart tools
description: Students identify examples of AI or "smart" technologies in their lives (e.g., a voice assistant that understands questions, a camera that recognizes faces, a game that learns your skill level) and understand that these are tools that are taught to make decisions, not tools with human-like thoughts.

title: Examine why people adopt new technologies
short_name: Why do people choose new technologies?
description: Students think about the reasons people adopt or use new technologies (e.g., saving time, solving a problem, following friends, ease of use) and consider whether those reasons are helpful or potentially harmful.

title: Trace the history of a technology over time
description: Students research or trace how a specific technology (e.g., phones, cameras, games, search engines) has evolved over time, noticing that technologies are not static and that changes respond to needs and user feedback.

title: Analyze roles of different people in creating a technology
short_name: Many people work together to make a technology
description: Students recognize that a single app, game, or device requires people from many fields: programmers, artists, designers, sound engineers, testers, marketers, etc. Each person has a role in determining how the final product affects users.

title: Evaluate an app or game for fairness and bias
short_name: Is this technology fair for everyone?
description: Students examine whether a technology, game, or app is fair and accessible to different groups (e.g., people with different abilities, languages, incomes, backgrounds). They identify potential biases or barriers.

title: Design a responsible technology feature
short_name: How would you make a game more responsible?
description: Students propose features or changes to an existing app or game to make it healthier or fairer (e.g., adding a "take a break" reminder, allowing players to pause, offering difficulty levels for different abilities, removing stereotypes).

title: Analyze how screen time affects learning and behavior
short_name: How does screen time affect us?
description: Students investigate research or personal observations about how extended screen use affects attention, sleep, social skills, physical health, and academic performance. They reason about causal relationships and tradeoffs.

title: Examine how AI and algorithms make decisions
short_name: How do AI systems decide what you see?
description: Students understand that AI systems in social media, recommendation apps, and search engines use algorithms to decide what information, ads, or content to show each user, and that these decisions can influence behavior and beliefs.

title: Evaluate environmental impacts of technology
short_name: How does making devices affect the environment?
description: Students learn that producing, transporting, and disposing of computing devices requires energy, materials, and water, and can cause pollution. They discuss tradeoffs between the benefits of technology and environmental cost.

title: Create a personal technology use plan
short_name: Design your own healthy tech habits
description: Students set personal goals and create a plan for balanced technology use, considering school, homework, social time, outdoor activity, and sleep. They reflect on what balance means for them.

title: Compare an emerging technology to older versions
short_name: Compare old technology to new technology
description: Students contrast an emerging technology (e.g., AI chatbots, AR filters) with the older technology it replaces or relates to, examining differences in features, speed, accessibility, and how they change the user experience across different communities.

title: Evaluate design decisions in a technology
short_name: How do design choices affect different users?
description: Students analyze how specific design decisions in a technology (e.g., interface color, game difficulty, notification frequency, language options) affect different groups of users differently, particularly underrepresented or marginalized groups.

title: Trace how a technology transformed a process
short_name: How did a technology change the way people work?
description: Students research how a technology (e.g., spreadsheets, email, video conferencing, online shopping) has fundamentally changed how a profession, business, or activity operates, examining both benefits and disruptions.

title: Identify expertise needed for an emerging technology
description: Students recognize that emerging technologies depend on knowledge from multiple fields (e.g., biology for medical AI, art for design, psychology for user experience, ethics for fairness) and that collaboration across disciplines is essential.

title: Analyze unintended systemic impacts of a technology
short_name: How does one technology change everything?
description: Students examine how a single technology can create ripple effects across society (e.g., smartphones enabling communication but also job displacement in certain sectors, social media enabling connection but also affecting mental health). They map systems and second-order effects.

title: Evaluate equity and access across communities
short_name: Do all communities benefit equally from a technology?
description: Students research or analyze whether access to and benefits from a technology (e.g., broadband, AI tools, smartphones) are equally distributed, and what happens when some communities lack access.

title: Examine the environmental life cycle of a technology
short_name: The full environmental impact of a device
description: Students trace the full environmental lifecycle of a computing device: extraction of materials, manufacturing, shipping, use, and disposal/recycling. They quantify or estimate the carbon footprint and waste.

title: Propose a technology solution with ethical considerations
description: Students propose a new technology (or improve an existing one) to solve a real problem while considering potential negative effects, equity, environmental impact, and privacy. They justify their approach.

title: Evaluate an emerging technology from multiple perspectives
short_name: Who benefits and who is harmed by a new technology?
description: Students evaluate a specific emerging technology (e.g., facial recognition, autonomous vehicles, AI in hiring) through the lens of different stakeholders (developers, users, workers affected by job loss, marginalized communities, environment) and explain how different groups have conflicting interests.

title: Analyze policy and regulation of an emerging technology
description: Students examine how governments and organizations regulate or should regulate emerging technologies (e.g., data privacy laws, AI transparency requirements, content moderation), weighing innovation, safety, freedom, and fairness.

title: Investigate personal data collection and privacy
short_name: What data do companies collect about you?
description: Students investigate what personal data apps and websites collect about them (location, behavior, preferences), how it is used (targeted ads, training AI), and what privacy risks this creates.

title: Create a presentation on responsible AI use
short_name: Communicate about AI impacts and responsibility
description: Students research an AI application (e.g., chatbots, image recognition, recommendation systems) and create a presentation or essay for peers addressing: what it does, who created it, intended benefits, known harms or biases, ethical concerns, and what responsible use looks like.

title: Why do people choose to use (or not use) a technology?
short_name: Explain a choice about using technology
topic_name: Ethics, Careers, Collaboration & Communication in CS
description: Students analyze real or hypothetical scenarios where a person chooses whether to use a technology (a smartphone, a gaming console, AI tool, video call) and explain the reasons: need, interest, consequences. They explore the idea that our choices about technology affect ourselves and others.

title: Fair and unfair in algorithms
short_name: Spot unfairness in how a computer decides
topic_name: Ethics, Careers, Collaboration & Communication in CS
description: Students recognize that a computer program (algorithm) can treat people differently or unfairly if not designed carefully. For example, a recommendation engine might only suggest certain types of games to boys or girls, or a filter might miss some faces. They begin to think critically about algorithm fairness.

title: Document your project so others understand
short_name: Write comments to explain your code
topic_name: Ethics, Careers, Collaboration & Communication in CS
description: Students add simple comments or descriptions to their CreatiCode projects so that someone else (a classmate, teacher, or future self) can understand what each part does. They learn that clear communication improves the quality of their work.

title: Work together fairly: roles and responsibilities
topic_name: Ethics, Careers, Collaboration & Communication in CS
description: Students practice assigning roles in a group project (idea person, builder, tester, presenter) so that everyone has a job and knows what they are responsible for. They understand that clear roles reduce conflict and help the team succeed.

title: Intended and unintended consequences
short_name: Predict good and bad effects of a technology
topic_name: Ethics, Careers, Collaboration & Communication in CS
description: Students investigate how a technology (social media, educational software, automation, AI tool) was designed to help people but can also cause unintended harm: making people lonely, spreading misinformation, losing jobs, violating privacy. They practice systems thinking—understanding that one change can ripple.

title: Is this data or algorithm fair to everyone?
short_name: Identify bias in data or a decision rule
topic_name: Ethics, Careers, Collaboration & Communication in CS
description: Students examine simple datasets or rules and spot patterns that might be unfair or biased. For example, a dataset of "successful coders" that includes mostly boys, or an algorithm that approves loans at different rates for different groups. They learn to question: "Who benefits? Who might be harmed?"

title: Create a presentation about your project
short_name: Make slides or a poster to show your work
topic_name: Ethics, Careers, Collaboration & Communication in CS
description: Students create a presentation (using CreatiCode presentation tools, slides, or poster format) that explains their project: what it does, how they built it, what was hard, and what they learned. They practice organizing information for an audience.

title: Ethics: Is my project respectful?
short_name: Check if your project treats people fairly
topic_name: Ethics, Careers, Collaboration & Communication in CS
description: Students reflect on a project they built or are planning: Does it include characters from different backgrounds? Does it stereotype anyone? Could it harm someone? They develop an internal ethical checklist when making creative computational work.

title: What are the limits of this technology?
short_name: Explain what a technology cannot do
topic_name: Ethics, Careers, Collaboration & Communication in CS
description: Students analyze a real technology and articulate its limitations: what it can't do well, who it doesn't help, what problems it doesn't solve. They develop critical, nuanced thinking about technology as a tool with boundaries, not a universal solution.

title: People from different jobs work together
short_name: Show how different experts collaborate with computing
topic_name: Ethics, Careers, Collaboration & Communication in CS
description: Students explore real examples where professionals from different fields (engineer, artist, biologist, teacher, doctor) work together using computing to solve a problem or create something. They see that computing bridges many disciplines and career paths.

title: Explain your project design choices
short_name: Document why you made certain choices
topic_name: Ethics, Careers, Collaboration & Communication in CS
description: Students write or present an explanation of the major design decisions in a completed CreatiCode project: why they chose certain characters, colors, rules, or features; how they thought about making it fair, fun, or accessible; what they would change if they had more time.

title: Respectful feedback and revision
topic_name: Ethics, Careers, Collaboration & Communication in CS
description: Students practice giving constructive criticism ("I liked ___ because ___. A suggestion: ___") and receiving feedback without defensiveness. They revise a project based on peer feedback, learning that iteration improves quality and that respect matters in critique.

title: Recognize bias in data and algorithms
short_name: Spot and analyze bias in real systems
topic_name: Ethics, Careers, Collaboration & Communication in CS
description: Students examine real or realistic examples of bias in data-driven systems: hiring algorithms that discriminate, facial recognition that works better for some skin tones, recommendation systems that exclude certain groups. They analyze why bias happens and propose improvements.

title: How computational thinking helps in different careers
short_name: Explain how professionals use CS to solve problems
topic_name: Ethics, Careers, Collaboration & Communication in CS
description: Students research professionals in various fields (medicine, environmental science, entertainment, business, sports) and explain how those professionals use computational thinking (breaking problems into steps, finding patterns, testing solutions) to do their work better.

title: Ethics in a career: dilemmas and decisions
short_name: Discuss ethical challenges in computing jobs
topic_name: Ethics, Careers, Collaboration & Communication in CS
description: Students explore scenarios where computing professionals face ethical dilemmas: Should we collect this data? Should this AI be deployed? Is this privacy violation worth the convenience? They practice reasoning through competing values and considering impacts on diverse groups.

title: Inclusive design: consider diverse users
short_name: Design for people with different abilities and needs
topic_name: Ethics, Careers, Collaboration & Communication in CS
description: Students apply inclusive design principles to a project: considering users with different physical abilities, language backgrounds, learning styles, and cultural contexts. They understand that thoughtful design makes technology better for everyone.

title: How tech transforms industries and jobs
short_name: Analyze how technology changes careers and industries
topic_name: Ethics, Careers, Collaboration & Communication in CS
description: Students examine a specific industry (agriculture, manufacturing, healthcare, entertainment) and trace how computing and automation have changed the jobs available, the skills needed, and the opportunities for workers. They consider both positive changes (new careers) and challenges (job displacement, need for retraining).

title: Ethical evaluation of emerging technologies
short_name: Evaluate a new technology for ethics and fairness
topic_name: Ethics, Careers, Collaboration & Communication in CS
description: Students select an emerging technology (AI, VR, IoT, blockchain, autonomous vehicles, facial recognition) and conduct a thorough ethical evaluation: What is it designed to do? Who benefits? Who might be harmed? Is it fair? Is it accessible? What policies should govern it?

title: Lead a team project with clear communication
short_name: Manage a collaborative project from start to finish
topic_name: Ethics, Careers, Collaboration & Communication in CS
description: Students take on a leadership role in a multi-person, multi-week CreatiCode project. They practice planning (breaking tasks into steps, assigning roles), communicating clearly (holding meetings, writing updates), managing time and conflicts, and presenting results professionally.

title: Reflect on fairness in your team and project
short_name: Assess your team's inclusivity and your project's fairness
topic_name: Ethics, Careers, Collaboration & Communication in CS
description: Students reflect on two aspects: (1) Did our team work fairly—did everyone contribute, were decisions made inclusively, was credit given? (2) Is our project inclusive and fair—does it include diverse characters, avoid stereotypes, work well for people with different abilities?

title: Analyze societal impacts of computing technologies
short_name: Examine how a technology impacts society and inequality
topic_name: Ethics, Careers, Collaboration & Communication in CS
description: Students conduct a research project analyzing how a widely used technology (social media, smartphones, AI assistants, cloud services, surveillance systems, e-commerce) impacts different groups of people, considering access, equity, environmental effects, cultural impacts, and power dynamics. They present nuanced, evidence-based arguments.

title: Explore a computing career pathway
short_name: Investigate a specific computing career and its requirements
topic_name: Ethics, Careers, Collaboration & Communication in CS
description: Students deep-dive into a computing-related career of interest (game developer, data scientist, cybersecurity specialist, AI researcher, software engineer, digital artist, tech policy analyst, etc.), researching education requirements, skills needed, salary range, daily tasks, and how computing interacts with their values and interests. They assess fit with their own aspirations.

title: Design a solution with ethics at the center
short_name: Create a project that solves a problem fairly
topic_name: Ethics, Careers, Collaboration & Communication in CS
description: Students identify a real problem or need (accessibility barrier, environmental challenge, educational gap, social issue) and design a CreatiCode project or prototype that attempts to solve it while explicitly considering: Who is this for? What biases might we introduce? How do we include diverse perspectives in the design? How will we know if it actually helps?

title: Communicate professionally about your work
short_name: Present your project professionally to diverse audiences
topic_name: Ethics, Careers, Collaboration & Communication in CS
description: Students develop a polished presentation or documentation of a substantial project suitable for multiple audiences (classmates, teachers, parents, competition judges, potential employers). They practice adapting their communication to audience, using technical vocabulary appropriately, and conveying both technical details and broader impact.
